div.head: Plan of this talk
div.p: We are interested in whether revenue monotonicity is achievable if we relax the assumption that mechanisms are deterministic.
In the rest of the talk I'll:
Extend our desirable properties to randomized CA mechanisms,
Show that there exist randomized CA mechanisms defined for known single-minded bidders, that satisfy our properties and are revenue monotonic.

div.p: Setting G: a set of m goods for sale N = {1, . . . , n}: the universal set of n bidders each may or may not participate in a given auction

div.head: Definition (Single-minded bidder)
div.p: A bidder i is single minded if she has the valuation function:
div.formula: ∀s ∈ 2 G , v i (s) = v i > 0 if s ⊇ b i ; 0 otherwise.

div.head: Definition (Known single-minded setting)
div.p: In a known single-minded setting, all bidders are single-minded and the bundles b i are known to the auctioneer. Adding a bidder never reduces the auction's expected revenue.

div.head: Definition (Participation)
div.p: A bidder makes zero expected payment if she does not win.

div.head: Definition (Maximality)
div.p: The chosen allocation is maximal: it cannot be augmented to make some bidders better off while making none worse off.

div.head: Randomized Mechanisms RM Mechanisms Conclusion
div.p: Consumer Sovereignty (I)

div.head: Definition (Consumer sovereignty (I))
div.p: Any bidder can win any bundle she desires with probability one if she bids high enough.
We recover the same impossibility result as with deterministic mechanisms.

div.head: Theorem
div.p: Let M be a randomized CA mechanism defined for known single-minded bidders that satisfies strategyproofness, participation, consumer sovereignty (I), and maximality. Then M is not revenue monotonic.

div.head: Randomized Mechanisms RM Mechanisms Conclusion
div.p: Consumer Sovereignty (II)

div.head: Definition (Consumer sovereignty (II))
div.p: Any bidder can win any bundle she desires with some probability above zero if she bids high enough.
There exists a (degenerate) mechanism that satisfies all our desired properties and consumer sovereignty (II).

div.head: Summary
div.p: There is no deterministic CA mechanism that satisfies strategyproofness, participation, consumer sovereignty, maximality, and revenue monotonicity.
In deterministic CA mechanisms, more bidders does not necessarily mean more competition.
There exist stepwise randomized CA mechanisms defined for known single-minded bidders that satisfy strategyproofness, participation, consumer sovereignty, maximality and revenue monotonicity.

div.p: Identify stepwise randomized mechanisms that maximize objective functions of interest.
E.g. identify those that maximize revenue.
